content: Practice patience. You need to be patient, since it can take a while to determine the right medication for you and it may take a few tries. You should give your medication four to six weeks to start working. [3] Recognize the long timeline. Antidepressants take different amounts of time to start working for different people. You may notice some benefit from a medication after only a day or two. However, it may take a few weeks or even a few months for the antidepressant to kick in. [4] If your antidepressant has not started working after six weeks, you should speak to your doctor about alternative medications. Watch for improvement in your symptoms. Use a diary to keep track of your symptoms on a daily basis. If you felt like your future was hopeless prior to starting the medication, you might want to consider how you feel about your future after taking the medication for two weeks. If you feel like you are slow and have a hard time concentrating, see if these symptoms have changed at all while on the medication. Use a depression screening test to track your symptoms. You can find depression screening scales online. Complete the symptom questionnaire and view your results to see if they change over time. [5] You can also use health diaries or mobile applications to track your symptoms. See if you feel any better. If you start to have more energy for the day and feel less depressed, this is a sign that your medication has started working. If you feel better after two to six weeks, this can be a very good sign. Identify side effects. Although the drug may be helping with some of your symptoms, it may also be resulting in side effects. You should pay attention to both any improvements and any side effects. Although the new wave of antidepressant types such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) have relatively fewer side effects than older types of medications, they still involve many side effects. These side effects commonly include a lower sex drive, a dry mouth, nausea, insomnia, anxiousness and restlessness, gaining weight, sleepiness, constipation and diarrhea. [6] Typically, side effects will emerge prior to the benefits of the treatment, so if you are experiencing side effects this may actually be a sign that the medication has started to work. However, you should also tell your doctor if you are experiencing side effects. If your side effects do not go away, you should talk to your doctor about alternative depression medication. [7] If some of your symptoms are getting better but you are experiencing unpleasant side effects, you should talk to your doctor. Watch for warning signs that the antidepressant is not working. It is important to look for signs that your antidepressant is not working. There are a variety of warning signs such as mood swings, suicidal thoughts and increased energy accompanied by the blues. In particular, keep an eye out for the following signs that your antidepressant is not working: If you feel you have way more energy but still feel down, this may be a bad sign. Some medications start working but do not function correctly for your condition. If this is the case, you will have more energy but will still feel blue. Talk to your doctor if this is the case. [8] If you feel better right away after starting a medication, it may be a sign that the medication may be inappropriate for you. [9] It usually takes a while for antidepressants to influence your brain chemistry. If you feel immediate improvement, you may be experiencing a side effect or placebo effect. In either case, talk to your doctor. If your depression gets worse or you start to experience horrible mood swings, this is a sign that your antidepressant is not working properly. You should talk to your doctor. [10] All antidepressants carry an increased risk of suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults between the ages of 18 and 24 during the first two months. If you or someone you know is contemplating suicide, has worsening depression, or has behavioral changes, contact a doctor immediately. Do not stopping taking your medication unless your doctor tells you to. Purchase a mental health application. A variety of mobile applications are available that help you track your depression. These applications have a variety of tools that can help you monitor your depression, learn new activities and communicate your experience to a medical professional. Download the Start application. The Start application, which is designed by Iodine and part of Apple’s Care Kit medical development tools, helps you track depression. It lets you share your data directly with a medical professional. [11] You take a short questionnaire at two week intervals, which is called the Patient Health Questionnaire. Taking the questionnaire helps you determine whether your symptoms have improved. You use the application for six weeks, and then use the results to decide with your doctor whether the medication is working. [12] Track your mood with the CBT Self-Help Guide. This is a smart phone diary application that helps you track how you relate and respond to events throughout your day. You write about events in your life, related moods and intensities. [13] This can help you track your depression while taking an antidepressant. If you start it prior to taking an antidepressant, you can use the diary application to determine if your mood has improved after starting an antidepressant. Download MoodKit. This application helps you monitor your mood and learn mood enhancing activities. It can be helpful for mild depression, but is not useful for people with moderate or severe depression. [14] In any case, it can be one tool, amongst others, to help you track your mood while taking antidepressants. Use the T2 Mood Tracker. This application helps you monitor your emotional states and includes a great graphing feature. It can help you monitor your depression so that you can more accurately report your experience to a mental health professional. [15] With accurate tracking and reporting to a mental health professional, you will have a better sense of whether or not the antidepressant is working. What’s My M3. This application helps you monitor your “M3 score,” which is a number that helps your doctor determine whether or not your mood disorder is treatable. [16] By tracking your M3 while on antidepressants, you can communicate your M3 score to your doctor. Communicate your experience of the antidepressant. Tell your mental health professional how you are feeling in response to the medication. If you have been using a mental health application, use the data you have gathered from monitoring your response to the antidepressant. If you use a diary, review your diary prior to visiting your mental health practitioner. By reviewing your diary, you will have a better sense of your moods, emotions, and responses to the medication. [17] If you have been using the same antidepressant for a long time and it isn’t working like it once did, you should tell your doctor. [18] Over time, your body may develop a tolerance to your antidepressant. This may cause your symptoms of depression to return. If you believe this is happening, talk to your doctor. They may adjust your dosage or change your medication. Ask your mental health professional. Using the information you gather from monitoring your mood while on the antidepressant, your doctor should be able to determine whether or not your antidepressant is working. Be sure to tell your doctor about any benefits you experience as well as any side effects that you are experiencing. Tell your doctor if you skipped any doses. Skipping doses is one cause of a faulty antidepressant, so you need to communicate that information to your doctor. [19] If you are taking other drugs or alcohol while on medication, you need to tell your doctor. This can be another reason for an antidepressant to stop working. If you are experiencing severe side effects, you may need to switch medications. Do not change your dosage or stop taking your antidepressant without consulting your doctor. Suddenly quitting the medication could worsen your depression or cause withdrawal symptoms. Your doctor can help you by slowly and safely decreasing the dose, if needed. [20] Inquire into alternative antidepressants. According to a large study, only 37% of people got better after trying just one antidepressant. [21] Your doctor should be able to determine whether or not your current antidepressant is working or whether you need to try a different type of medication. The most popular antidepressants are SSRIs and SNRIs. Another common medication is bupropion, which belongs to a class of antidepressants known as NDRIs. Bupropion is used for depression, seasonal affective disorder and quitting smoking. [22] In addition, there are older types of depression medications such as tricyclics, monoamine oxidase inhibitors and tetracyclics. People respond differently to depression medication so you need to work out a treatment plan with your doctor for your specific condition. You might need to try a different type of antidepressant if your current one is not working. [23] Consider psychotherapy. Combining antidepressant drug therapy with mental health counseling like psychotherapy is usually more effective than taking the drug alone. [24] There are multiple forms of psychotherapy that might help. These include: Cognitive Behavior Therapy: this form of therapy helps you change your way of thinking by identifying how you currently perceive the world and yourself. The therapist will help you create healthier patterns of thinking. Interpersonal Therapy: this form of therapy helps depression caused by family conflict, loss, relationship problems, social isolation, and major life events such as giving birth. Psychodynamic Therapy: the therapist helps you resolve unconscious conflicts, like childhood trauma. [25]

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Know-if-Antidepressants-Are-Working">How to Know if Antidepressants Are Working</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Jennifer Boidy, RN</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Identifying_Signs_that_Your_Antidepressant_is_Working_sub" id="">Identifying Signs that Your Antidepressant is Working</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Tracking_Your_Symptoms_with_an_Application_sub" id="">Tracking Your Symptoms with an Application</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Talking_to_Your_Doctor_or_Psychiatrist_sub" id="">Talking to Your Doctor or Psychiatrist</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Questions & Answers</a>
<a class="" href="#relatedwikihows" id="rwh_toc">Related Articles</a>
<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=jenniferboidy%2Crn#jenniferboidy%2Crn">Jennifer Boidy, RN</a>. Jennifer Boidy is a Registered Nurse in Maryland. She received her Associate of Science in Nursing from Carroll Community College in 2012.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">25 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Antidepressants are commonly used alongside other forms of therapy to treat depression. It is difficult to know whether your antidepressant medications are working because they may take a while to start functioning properly. Typically, they take four to six weeks to start working.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> Once your medications start working, you may notice some of the side effects and eventually benefits like more energy and a more positive outlook on life. If your medications do not work for you or result in too many side effects, you may need to switch antidepressants. Common antidepressants include selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRIs), serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs), and norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitors (NDRIs) as well as older drugs like tricyclics and tetracyclics.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> Your doctor will give you advice on whether your antidepressant is working and what your alternatives may be, depending on your condition.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Identifying_Signs_that_Your_Antidepressant_is_Working_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Identifying_Signs_that_Your_Antidepressant_is_Working">Identifying Signs that Your Antidepressant is Working</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Prevent-Spotting-on-Birth-Control-Step-1-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Prevent-Spotting-on-Birth-Control-Step-1-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Prevent Spotting on Birth Control Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Prevent-Spotting-on-Birth-Control-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Prevent-Spotting-on-Birth-Control-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_31a11630dd" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_31a11630dd')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Prevent Spotting on Birth Control Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Prevent-Spotting-on-Birth-Control-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Prevent-Spotting-on-Birth-Control-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Practice patience.</b> You need to be patient, since it can take a while to determine the right medication for you and it may take a few tries. You should give your medication four to six weeks to start working.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Recognize the long timeline. Antidepressants take different amounts of time to start working for different people. You may notice some benefit from a medication after only a day or two. However, it may take a few weeks or even a few months for the antidepressant to kick in.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If your antidepressant has not started working after six weeks, you should speak to your doctor about alternative medications.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Set-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Set-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Set Goals Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Set-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Set-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_e3b8a789b0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e3b8a789b0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Set Goals Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/65/Set-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Set-Goals-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Watch for improvement in your symptoms.</b> Use a diary to keep track of your symptoms on a daily basis. If you felt like your future was hopeless prior to starting the medication, you might want to consider how you feel about your future after taking the medication for two weeks. If you feel like you are slow and have a hard time concentrating, see if these symptoms have changed at all while on the medication.

<ul>
<li>Use a depression screening test to track your symptoms. You can find depression screening scales online. Complete the symptom questionnaire and view your results to see if they change over time.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>You can also use health diaries or mobile applications to track your symptoms.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-a-Man-Step-14-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Be-a-Man-Step-14-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be a Man Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Be-a-Man-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Be-a-Man-Step-14-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_664454fa13" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_664454fa13')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be a Man Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Be-a-Man-Step-14-Version-3.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Be-a-Man-Step-14-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">See if you feel any better.</b> If you start to have more energy for the day and feel less depressed, this is a sign that your medication has started working. If you feel better after two to six weeks, this can be a very good sign.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Best-Absorb-Magnesium-Supplements-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Best-Absorb-Magnesium-Supplements-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Best Absorb Magnesium Supplements Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/30/Best-Absorb-Magnesium-Supplements-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Best-Absorb-Magnesium-Supplements-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c4e3ba598a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c4e3ba598a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Best Absorb Magnesium Supplements Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/30/Best-Absorb-Magnesium-Supplements-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Best-Absorb-Magnesium-Supplements-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Identify side effects.</b> Although the drug may be helping with some of your symptoms, it may also be resulting in side effects. You should pay attention to both any improvements and any side effects. Although the new wave of antidepressant types such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) have relatively fewer side effects than older types of medications, they still involve many side effects. These side effects commonly include a lower sex drive, a dry mouth, nausea, insomnia, anxiousness and restlessness, gaining weight, sleepiness, constipation and diarrhea.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Typically, side effects will emerge prior to the benefits of the treatment, so if you are experiencing side effects this may actually be a sign that the medication has started to work. However, you should also tell your doctor if you are experiencing side effects.

<ul>
<li>If your side effects do not go away, you should talk to your doctor about alternative depression medication.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If some of your symptoms are getting better but you are experiencing unpleasant side effects, you should talk to your doctor.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Elevate-Your-Self-Esteem-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Elevate-Your-Self-Esteem-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Elevate Your Self Esteem Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Elevate-Your-Self-Esteem-Step-9.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Elevate-Your-Self-Esteem-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_c6ef8910a8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c6ef8910a8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Elevate Your Self Esteem Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4b/Elevate-Your-Self-Esteem-Step-9.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Elevate-Your-Self-Esteem-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Watch for warning signs that the antidepressant is not working.</b> It is important to look for signs that your antidepressant is not working. There are a variety of warning signs such as mood swings, suicidal thoughts and increased energy accompanied by the blues. In particular, keep an eye out for the following signs that your antidepressant is not working:

<ul>
<li>If you feel you have way more energy but still feel down, this may be a bad sign. Some medications start working but do not function correctly for your condition. If this is the case, you will have more energy but will still feel blue. Talk to your doctor if this is the case.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If you feel better right away after starting a medication, it may be a sign that the medication may be inappropriate for you.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup> It usually takes a while for antidepressants to influence your brain chemistry. If you feel immediate improvement, you may be experiencing a side effect or placebo effect. In either case, talk to your doctor.</li>
<li>If your depression gets worse or you start to experience horrible mood swings, this is a sign that your antidepressant is not working properly. You should talk to your doctor.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>All antidepressants carry an increased risk of suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults between the ages of 18 and 24 during the first two months. If you or someone you know is contemplating suicide, has worsening depression, or has behavioral changes, contact a doctor immediately. Do not stopping taking your medication unless your doctor tells you to.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Tracking_Your_Symptoms_with_an_Application_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Tracking_Your_Symptoms_with_an_Application">Tracking Your Symptoms with an Application</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Your-Cell-Phone-Battery-Last-Longer-Step-13-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Make-Your-Cell-Phone-Battery-Last-Longer-Step-13-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Your Cell Phone Battery Last Longer Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Make-Your-Cell-Phone-Battery-Last-Longer-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Make-Your-Cell-Phone-Battery-Last-Longer-Step-13-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_557791d1d0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_557791d1d0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Your Cell Phone Battery Last Longer Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Make-Your-Cell-Phone-Battery-Last-Longer-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Make-Your-Cell-Phone-Battery-Last-Longer-Step-13-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Purchase a mental health application.</b> A variety of mobile applications are available that help you track your depression. These applications have a variety of tools that can help you monitor your depression, learn new activities and communicate your experience to a medical professional.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Call-Back-a-Blocked-Number-Step-7-Version-4.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Call-Back-a-Blocked-Number-Step-7-Version-4.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Call Back a Blocked Number Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Call-Back-a-Blocked-Number-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Call-Back-a-Blocked-Number-Step-7-Version-4.jpg" height="546" id="img_73111e86e8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_73111e86e8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Call Back a Blocked Number Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Call-Back-a-Blocked-Number-Step-7-Version-4.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Call-Back-a-Blocked-Number-Step-7-Version-4.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Download the Start application.</b> The Start application, which is designed by Iodine and part of Apple’s Care Kit medical development tools, helps you track depression. It lets you share your data directly with a medical professional.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup> You take a short questionnaire at two week intervals, which is called the Patient Health Questionnaire. Taking the questionnaire helps you determine whether your symptoms have improved. You use the application for six weeks, and then use the results to decide with your doctor whether the medication is working.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Have-Phone-Sex-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Have-Phone-Sex-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Have Phone Sex Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8f/Have-Phone-Sex-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Have-Phone-Sex-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_9d865c1dbf" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9d865c1dbf')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Have Phone Sex Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8f/Have-Phone-Sex-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Have-Phone-Sex-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Track your mood with the CBT Self-Help Guide.</b> This is a smart phone diary application that helps you track how you relate and respond to events throughout your day. You write about events in your life, related moods and intensities.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup> This can help you track your depression while taking an antidepressant. If you start it prior to taking an antidepressant, you can use the diary application to determine if your mood has improved after starting an antidepressant.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Ask-a-Girl-Out-over-Text-Step-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Ask-a-Girl-Out-over-Text-Step-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Ask a Girl Out over Text Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/71/Ask-a-Girl-Out-over-Text-Step-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Ask-a-Girl-Out-over-Text-Step-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_2dca6a7b78" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2dca6a7b78')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Ask a Girl Out over Text Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/71/Ask-a-Girl-Out-over-Text-Step-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Ask-a-Girl-Out-over-Text-Step-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Download MoodKit.</b> This application helps you monitor your mood and learn mood enhancing activities. It can be helpful for mild depression, but is not useful for people with moderate or severe depression.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup> In any case, it can be one tool, amongst others, to help you track your mood while taking antidepressants.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Trace-Cell-Phone-Numbers-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Trace-Cell-Phone-Numbers-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Trace Cell Phone Numbers Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Trace-Cell-Phone-Numbers-Step-6.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Trace-Cell-Phone-Numbers-Step-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_a7bcc241d4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a7bcc241d4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Trace Cell Phone Numbers Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c3/Trace-Cell-Phone-Numbers-Step-6.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Trace-Cell-Phone-Numbers-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use the T2 Mood Tracker.</b> This application helps you monitor your emotional states and includes a great graphing feature. It can help you monitor your depression so that you can more accurately report your experience to a mental health professional.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup> With accurate tracking and reporting to a mental health professional, you will have a better sense of whether or not the antidepressant is working.

<ul>
<li>What’s My M3. This application helps you monitor your “M3 score,” which is a number that helps your doctor determine whether or not your mood disorder is treatable.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup> By tracking your M3 while on antidepressants, you can communicate your M3 score to your doctor.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Talking_to_Your_Doctor_or_Psychiatrist_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Talking_to_Your_Doctor_or_Psychiatrist">Talking to Your Doctor or Psychiatrist</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Overcome-Sadness-Step-32.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Overcome-Sadness-Step-32.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Overcome Sadness Step 32" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Overcome-Sadness-Step-32.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Overcome-Sadness-Step-32.jpg" height="546" id="img_7676eb2f34" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7676eb2f34')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Overcome Sadness Step 32" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Overcome-Sadness-Step-32.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Overcome-Sadness-Step-32.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Communicate your experience of the antidepressant.</b> Tell your mental health professional how you are feeling in response to the medication. If you have been using a mental health application, use the data you have gathered from monitoring your response to the antidepressant.

<ul>
<li>If you use a diary, review your diary prior to visiting your mental health practitioner. By reviewing your diary, you will have a better sense of your moods, emotions, and responses to the medication.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If you have been using the same antidepressant for a long time and it isn’t working like it once did, you should tell your doctor.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 18" class="reference" id="_ref-18"><a href="#_note-18">[18]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Over time, your body may develop a tolerance to your antidepressant. This may cause your symptoms of depression to return. If you believe this is happening, talk to your doctor. They may adjust your dosage or change your medication.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Remove-a-Cyst-on-Your-Face-Step-10-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Remove-a-Cyst-on-Your-Face-Step-10-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Remove a Cyst on Your Face Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Remove-a-Cyst-on-Your-Face-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Remove-a-Cyst-on-Your-Face-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_98538d9d40" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_98538d9d40')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Remove a Cyst on Your Face Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/39/Remove-a-Cyst-on-Your-Face-Step-10-Version-2.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Remove-a-Cyst-on-Your-Face-Step-10-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ask your mental health professional.</b> Using the information you gather from monitoring your mood while on the antidepressant, your doctor should be able to determine whether or not your antidepressant is working. Be sure to tell your doctor about any benefits you experience as well as any side effects that you are experiencing.

<ul>
<li>Tell your doctor if you skipped any doses. Skipping doses is one cause of a faulty antidepressant, so you need to communicate that information to your doctor.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If you are taking other drugs or alcohol while on medication, you need to tell your doctor. This can be another reason for an antidepressant to stop working.</li>
<li>If you are experiencing severe side effects, you may need to switch medications.</li>
<li>Do not change your dosage or stop taking your antidepressant without consulting your doctor. Suddenly quitting the medication could worsen your depression or cause withdrawal symptoms. Your doctor can help you by slowly and safely decreasing the dose, if needed.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-Yourself-Sleepy-Step-8-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Make-Yourself-Sleepy-Step-8-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make Yourself Sleepy Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Make-Yourself-Sleepy-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Make-Yourself-Sleepy-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_a8f772b4ab" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a8f772b4ab')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make Yourself Sleepy Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Make-Yourself-Sleepy-Step-8-Version-3.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Make-Yourself-Sleepy-Step-8-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Inquire into alternative antidepressants.</b> According to a large study, only 37% of people got better after trying just one antidepressant.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup> Your doctor should be able to determine whether or not your current antidepressant is working or whether you need to try a different type of medication.

<ul>
<li>The most popular antidepressants are SSRIs and SNRIs. Another common medication is bupropion, which belongs to a class of antidepressants known as NDRIs. Bupropion is used for depression, seasonal affective disorder and quitting smoking.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 22" class="reference" id="_ref-22"><a href="#_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>In addition, there are older types of depression medications such as tricyclics, monoamine oxidase inhibitors and tetracyclics. People respond differently to depression medication so you need to work out a treatment plan with your doctor for your specific condition. You might need to try a different type of antidepressant if your current one is not working.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 23" class="reference" id="_ref-23"><a href="#_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Get-Rid-of-Morning-Breath-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=8119871" href="#/Image:Get-Rid-of-Morning-Breath-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Morning Breath Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Get-Rid-of-Morning-Breath-Step-15.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Morning-Breath-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_537ccb5c91" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_537ccb5c91')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Get Rid of Morning Breath Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Get-Rid-of-Morning-Breath-Step-15.jpg/aid8119871-v4-728px-Get-Rid-of-Morning-Breath-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider psychotherapy.</b> Combining antidepressant drug therapy with mental health counseling like psychotherapy is usually more effective than taking the drug alone.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 24" class="reference" id="_ref-24"><a href="#_note-24">[24]</a></sup> There are multiple forms of psychotherapy that might help. These include:

<ul>
<li>
<b>Cognitive Behavior Therapy:</b> this form of therapy helps you change your way of thinking by identifying how you currently perceive the world and yourself. The therapist will help you create healthier patterns of thinking.</li>
<li>
<b>Interpersonal Therapy:</b> this form of therapy helps depression caused by family conflict, loss, relationship problems, social isolation, and major life events such as giving birth.</li>
<li>
<b>Psychodynamic Therapy:</b> the therapist helps you resolve unconscious conflicts, like childhood trauma.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 25" class="reference" id="_ref-25"><a href="#_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Questions_and_Answers_sub"></a>
<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="8119871" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">
<div class="qa_section_heading" id="qa_aq_search_heading">Search</div>
<input class="qa_aq_search" placeholder="Type your query here"/>
</div>
<a id="qa_add_curated_question">Add New Question</a>
<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="293663" data-caid="294536" data-cqid="293680" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1797246" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="3">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I started a new anti-depressant 5 weeks ago, and have been feeling side effects from start. When will I know if it is working?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">You may need to give it a little more time, as many medications take 6 weeks or longer to become fully effective. It's a good idea to consult with your doctor. Never start or stop taking an anti-depressant without consulting your doctor. If you feel suicidal, seek help immediately. </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>3</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="492294" data-caid="493167" data-cqid="492311" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2575653" data-submitter_id="4865611" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="1">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I am on Effexor 300ml. 4 months. I feel some improvements but very little. Still have lots of anxiety. Should I give it more time?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-zVKjdldrvU4/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAATY/eV1sSfLzfh8/s96-c/photo.jpg)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Sarah-Paskow">Sarah Paskow</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Some medications can take 4 months to even start working. I would wait another couple months UNLESS you are having/feeling suicidal thought or actions. if so, seek professional help right away.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>1</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>1</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="357448" data-caid="358321" data-cqid="357465" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1940332" data-submitter_id="1977439" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="1" data-votes_up="1">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I have been on Zoloft 50 mg for 7 weeks, but I still don't feel like my old self. Will it take longer or should I have it increased?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://www.wikihow.com/images/avatarOut/f/f1/1977439.jpg?20170918162104)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Sonamoni">Sonamoni</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Try asking your doctor about what you should do if your medication doesn't work.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>1</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>1</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="492304" data-caid="493177" data-cqid="492321" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="2258077" data-submitter_id="4865611" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="0">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I've been on Pristiq for the past 5 years. It helps me not spiral down deep, but I still have depression come and go, and it hasn't really helped me in any other way. Should I expect more from antidepressants?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle" style="background-image:url(https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-zVKjdldrvU4/AAAAAAAAAAI/AAAAAAAAATY/eV1sSfLzfh8/s96-c/photo.jpg)"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"><span class="qa_user_link" data-href="/User:Sarah-Paskow">Sarah Paskow</span></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">I would recommend you tell your psychiatrist (or whoever prescribes your Pristiq) about this and ask about getting another antidepressant to work in tandem with your Pristiq.  </div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">Yes</a>
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>0</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
</div>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Know if Antidepressants Are Working",
    "name": "Know if Antidepressants Are Working",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "id": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/Know-if-Antidepressants-Are-Working"
    },
    "image": {
        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/69\/Get-Rid-of-Morning-Breath-Step-15.jpg\/aid8119871-v4-1200px-Get-Rid-of-Morning-Breath-Step-15.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "aggregateRating": {
        "@type": "AggregateRating",
        "bestRating": 100,
        "ratingCount": 27,
        "ratingValue": 81
    },
    "datePublished": "2016-10-11",
    "dateModified": "2019-03-29",
    "publisher": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "contributor": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Jennifer Boidy, RN"
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Identifying Signs that Your Antidepressant is Working",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Practice patience. You need to be patient, since it can take a while to determine the right medication for you and it may take a few tries. You should give your medication four to six weeks to start working.[3]\nRecognize the long timeline. Antidepressants take different amounts of time to start working for different people. You may notice some benefit from a medication after only a day or two. However, it may take a few weeks or even a few months for the antidepressant to kick in.[4]\nIf your antidepressant has not started working after six weeks, you should speak to your doctor about alternative medications."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Watch for improvement in your symptoms. Use a diary to keep track of your symptoms on a daily basis. If you felt like your future was hopeless prior to starting the medication, you might want to consider how you feel about your future after taking the medication for two weeks. If you feel like you are slow and have a hard time concentrating, see if these symptoms have changed at all while on the medication.\n\nUse a depression screening test to track your symptoms. You can find depression screening scales online. Complete the symptom questionnaire and view your results to see if they change over time.[5]\nYou can also use health diaries or mobile applications to track your symptoms."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "See if you feel any better. If you start to have more energy for the day and feel less depressed, this is a sign that your medication has started working. If you feel better after two to six weeks, this can be a very good sign."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Identify side effects. Although the drug may be helping with some of your symptoms, it may also be resulting in side effects. You should pay attention to both any improvements and any side effects. Although the new wave of antidepressant types such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) have relatively fewer side effects than older types of medications, they still involve many side effects. These side effects commonly include a lower sex drive, a dry mouth, nausea, insomnia, anxiousness and restlessness, gaining weight, sleepiness, constipation and diarrhea.[6] Typically, side effects will emerge prior to the benefits of the treatment, so if you are experiencing side effects this may actually be a sign that the medication has started to work. However, you should also tell your doctor if you are experiencing side effects.\n\nIf your side effects do not go away, you should talk to your doctor about alternative depression medication.[7]\nIf some of your symptoms are getting better but you are experiencing unpleasant side effects, you should talk to your doctor."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Watch for warning signs that the antidepressant is not working. It is important to look for signs that your antidepressant is not working. There are a variety of warning signs such as mood swings, suicidal thoughts and increased energy accompanied by the blues. In particular, keep an eye out for the following signs that your antidepressant is not working:\n\nIf you feel you have way more energy but still feel down, this may be a bad sign. Some medications start working but do not function correctly for your condition. If this is the case, you will have more energy but will still feel blue. Talk to your doctor if this is the case.[8]\nIf you feel better right away after starting a medication, it may be a sign that the medication may be inappropriate for you.[9] It usually takes a while for antidepressants to influence your brain chemistry. If you feel immediate improvement, you may be experiencing a side effect or placebo effect. In either case, talk to your doctor.\nIf your depression gets worse or you start to experience horrible mood swings, this is a sign that your antidepressant is not working properly. You should talk to your doctor.[10]\nAll antidepressants carry an increased risk of suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults between the ages of 18 and 24 during the first two months. If you or someone you know is contemplating suicide, has worsening depression, or has behavioral changes, contact a doctor immediately. Do not stopping taking your medication unless your doctor tells you to."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Tracking Your Symptoms with an Application",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Purchase a mental health application. A variety of mobile applications are available that help you track your depression. These applications have a variety of tools that can help you monitor your depression, learn new activities and communicate your experience to a medical professional."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Download the Start application. The Start application, which is designed by Iodine and part of Apple\u2019s Care Kit medical development tools, helps you track depression. It lets you share your data directly with a medical professional.[11] You take a short questionnaire at two week intervals, which is called the Patient Health Questionnaire. Taking the questionnaire helps you determine whether your symptoms have improved. You use the application for six weeks, and then use the results to decide with your doctor whether the medication is working.[12]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Track your mood with the CBT Self-Help Guide. This is a smart phone diary application that helps you track how you relate and respond to events throughout your day. You write about events in your life, related moods and intensities.[13] This can help you track your depression while taking an antidepressant. If you start it prior to taking an antidepressant, you can use the diary application to determine if your mood has improved after starting an antidepressant."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Download MoodKit. This application helps you monitor your mood and learn mood enhancing activities. It can be helpful for mild depression, but is not useful for people with moderate or severe depression.[14] In any case, it can be one tool, amongst others, to help you track your mood while taking antidepressants."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use the T2 Mood Tracker. This application helps you monitor your emotional states and includes a great graphing feature. It can help you monitor your depression so that you can more accurately report your experience to a mental health professional.[15] With accurate tracking and reporting to a mental health professional, you will have a better sense of whether or not the antidepressant is working.\n\nWhat\u2019s My M3. This application helps you monitor your \u201cM3 score,\u201d which is a number that helps your doctor determine whether or not your mood disorder is treatable.[16] By tracking your M3 while on antidepressants, you can communicate your M3 score to your doctor."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Talking to Your Doctor or Psychiatrist",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Communicate your experience of the antidepressant. Tell your mental health professional how you are feeling in response to the medication. If you have been using a mental health application, use the data you have gathered from monitoring your response to the antidepressant.\n\nIf you use a diary, review your diary prior to visiting your mental health practitioner. By reviewing your diary, you will have a better sense of your moods, emotions, and responses to the medication.[17]\nIf you have been using the same antidepressant for a long time and it isn\u2019t working like it once did, you should tell your doctor.[18]\nOver time, your body may develop a tolerance to your antidepressant. This may cause your symptoms of depression to return. If you believe this is happening, talk to your doctor. They may adjust your dosage or change your medication."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Ask your mental health professional. Using the information you gather from monitoring your mood while on the antidepressant, your doctor should be able to determine whether or not your antidepressant is working. Be sure to tell your doctor about any benefits you experience as well as any side effects that you are experiencing.\n\nTell your doctor if you skipped any doses. Skipping doses is one cause of a faulty antidepressant, so you need to communicate that information to your doctor.[19]\nIf you are taking other drugs or alcohol while on medication, you need to tell your doctor. This can be another reason for an antidepressant to stop working.\nIf you are experiencing severe side effects, you may need to switch medications.\nDo not change your dosage or stop taking your antidepressant without consulting your doctor. Suddenly quitting the medication could worsen your depression or cause withdrawal symptoms. Your doctor can help you by slowly and safely decreasing the dose, if needed.[20]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Inquire into alternative antidepressants. According to a large study, only 37% of people got better after trying just one antidepressant.[21] Your doctor should be able to determine whether or not your current antidepressant is working or whether you need to try a different type of medication.\n\nThe most popular antidepressants are SSRIs and SNRIs. Another common medication is bupropion, which belongs to a class of antidepressants known as NDRIs. Bupropion is used for depression, seasonal affective disorder and quitting smoking.[22]\nIn addition, there are older types of depression medications such as tricyclics, monoamine oxidase inhibitors and tetracyclics. People respond differently to depression medication so you need to work out a treatment plan with your doctor for your specific condition. You might need to try a different type of antidepressant if your current one is not working.[23]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Consider psychotherapy. Combining antidepressant drug therapy with mental health counseling like psychotherapy is usually more effective than taking the drug alone.[24] There are multiple forms of psychotherapy that might help. These include:\n\n\nCognitive Behavior Therapy: this form of therapy helps you change your way of thinking by identifying how you currently perceive the world and yourself. The therapist will help you create healthier patterns of thinking.\n\nInterpersonal Therapy: this form of therapy helps depression caused by family conflict, loss, relationship problems, social isolation, and major life events such as giving birth.\n\nPsychodynamic Therapy: the therapist helps you resolve unconscious conflicts, like childhood trauma.[25]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        }
    ],
    "description": "How to Know if Antidepressants Are Working. Antidepressants are commonly used alongside other forms of therapy to treat depression. It is difficult to know whether your antidepressant medications are working because they may take a while..."
}</script>

title: How to Know if Antidepressants Are Working
content_html:
Practice patience. You need to be patient, since it can take a while to determine the right medication for you and it may take a few tries. You should give your medication four to six weeks to start working.[3]
  • Recognize the long timeline. Antidepressants take different amounts of time to start working for different people. You may notice some benefit from a medication after only a day or two. However, it may take a few weeks or even a few months for the antidepressant to kick in.[4]
  • If your antidepressant has not started working after six weeks, you should speak to your doctor about alternative medications.
Watch for improvement in your symptoms. Use a diary to keep track of your symptoms on a daily basis. If you felt like your future was hopeless prior to starting the medication, you might want to consider how you feel about your future after taking the medication for two weeks. If you feel like you are slow and have a hard time concentrating, see if these symptoms have changed at all while on the medication.
  • Use a depression screening test to track your symptoms. You can find depression screening scales online. Complete the symptom questionnaire and view your results to see if they change over time.[5]
  • You can also use health diaries or mobile applications to track your symptoms.
See if you feel any better. If you start to have more energy for the day and feel less depressed, this is a sign that your medication has started working. If you feel better after two to six weeks, this can be a very good sign.
Identify side effects. Although the drug may be helping with some of your symptoms, it may also be resulting in side effects. You should pay attention to both any improvements and any side effects. Although the new wave of antidepressant types such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) have relatively fewer side effects than older types of medications, they still involve many side effects. These side effects commonly include a lower sex drive, a dry mouth, nausea, insomnia, anxiousness and restlessness, gaining weight, sleepiness, constipation and diarrhea.[6] Typically, side effects will emerge prior to the benefits of the treatment, so if you are experiencing side effects this may actually be a sign that the medication has started to work. However, you should also tell your doctor if you are experiencing side effects.
  • If your side effects do not go away, you should talk to your doctor about alternative depression medication.[7]
  • If some of your symptoms are getting better but you are experiencing unpleasant side effects, you should talk to your doctor.
Watch for warning signs that the antidepressant is not working. It is important to look for signs that your antidepressant is not working. There are a variety of warning signs such as mood swings, suicidal thoughts and increased energy accompanied by the blues. In particular, keep an eye out for the following signs that your antidepressant is not working:
  • If you feel you have way more energy but still feel down, this may be a bad sign. Some medications start working but do not function correctly for your condition. If this is the case, you will have more energy but will still feel blue. Talk to your doctor if this is the case.[8]
  • If you feel better right away after starting a medication, it may be a sign that the medication may be inappropriate for you.[9] It usually takes a while for antidepressants to influence your brain chemistry. If you feel immediate improvement, you may be experiencing a side effect or placebo effect. In either case, talk to your doctor.
  • If your depression gets worse or you start to experience horrible mood swings, this is a sign that your antidepressant is not working properly. You should talk to your doctor.[10]
  • All antidepressants carry an increased risk of suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults between the ages of 18 and 24 during the first two months. If you or someone you know is contemplating suicide, has worsening depression, or has behavioral changes, contact a doctor immediately. Do not stopping taking your medication unless your doctor tells you to.
Purchase a mental health application. A variety of mobile applications are available that help you track your depression. These applications have a variety of tools that can help you monitor your depression, learn new activities and communicate your experience to a medical professional.
Download the Start application. The Start application, which is designed by Iodine and part of Apple’s Care Kit medical development tools, helps you track depression. It lets you share your data directly with a medical professional.[11] You take a short questionnaire at two week intervals, which is called the Patient Health Questionnaire. Taking the questionnaire helps you determine whether your symptoms have improved. You use the application for six weeks, and then use the results to decide with your doctor whether the medication is working.[12]
Track your mood with the CBT Self-Help Guide. This is a smart phone diary application that helps you track how you relate and respond to events throughout your day. You write about events in your life, related moods and intensities.[13] This can help you track your depression while taking an antidepressant. If you start it prior to taking an antidepressant, you can use the diary application to determine if your mood has improved after starting an antidepressant.
Download MoodKit. This application helps you monitor your mood and learn mood enhancing activities. It can be helpful for mild depression, but is not useful for people with moderate or severe depression.[14] In any case, it can be one tool, amongst others, to help you track your mood while taking antidepressants.
Use the T2 Mood Tracker. This application helps you monitor your emotional states and includes a great graphing feature. It can help you monitor your depression so that you can more accurately report your experience to a mental health professional.[15] With accurate tracking and reporting to a mental health professional, you will have a better sense of whether or not the antidepressant is working.
  • What’s My M3. This application helps you monitor your “M3 score,” which is a number that helps your doctor determine whether or not your mood disorder is treatable.[16] By tracking your M3 while on antidepressants, you can communicate your M3 score to your doctor.
Communicate your experience of the antidepressant. Tell your mental health professional how you are feeling in response to the medication. If you have been using a mental health application, use the data you have gathered from monitoring your response to the antidepressant.
  • If you use a diary, review your diary prior to visiting your mental health practitioner. By reviewing your diary, you will have a better sense of your moods, emotions, and responses to the medication.[17]
  • If you have been using the same antidepressant for a long time and it isn’t working like it once did, you should tell your doctor.[18]
  • Over time, your body may develop a tolerance to your antidepressant. This may cause your symptoms of depression to return. If you believe this is happening, talk to your doctor. They may adjust your dosage or change your medication.
Ask your mental health professional. Using the information you gather from monitoring your mood while on the antidepressant, your doctor should be able to determine whether or not your antidepressant is working. Be sure to tell your doctor about any benefits you experience as well as any side effects that you are experiencing.
  • Tell your doctor if you skipped any doses. Skipping doses is one cause of a faulty antidepressant, so you need to communicate that information to your doctor.[19]
  • If you are taking other drugs or alcohol while on medication, you need to tell your doctor. This can be another reason for an antidepressant to stop working.
  • If you are experiencing severe side effects, you may need to switch medications.
  • Do not change your dosage or stop taking your antidepressant without consulting your doctor. Suddenly quitting the medication could worsen your depression or cause withdrawal symptoms. Your doctor can help you by slowly and safely decreasing the dose, if needed.[20]
Inquire into alternative antidepressants. According to a large study, only 37% of people got better after trying just one antidepressant.[21] Your doctor should be able to determine whether or not your current antidepressant is working or whether you need to try a different type of medication.
  • The most popular antidepressants are SSRIs and SNRIs. Another common medication is bupropion, which belongs to a class of antidepressants known as NDRIs. Bupropion is used for depression, seasonal affective disorder and quitting smoking.[22]
  • In addition, there are older types of depression medications such as tricyclics, monoamine oxidase inhibitors and tetracyclics. People respond differently to depression medication so you need to work out a treatment plan with your doctor for your specific condition. You might need to try a different type of antidepressant if your current one is not working.[23]
Consider psychotherapy. Combining antidepressant drug therapy with mental health counseling like psychotherapy is usually more effective than taking the drug alone.[24] There are multiple forms of psychotherapy that might help. These include:
  • Cognitive Behavior Therapy: this form of therapy helps you change your way of thinking by identifying how you currently perceive the world and yourself. The therapist will help you create healthier patterns of thinking.
  • Interpersonal Therapy: this form of therapy helps depression caused by family conflict, loss, relationship problems, social isolation, and major life events such as giving birth.
  • Psychodynamic Therapy: the therapist helps you resolve unconscious conflicts, like childhood trauma.[25]
